abstract.p: Securities trading systems have settlement efficiency, audit transparency, and fraud prevention concerns due to centralized intermediaries and aging infrastructure. Existing research models risk counterparty trading due to delayed settlements, opaque record keeping, and human compliance checks. The study aims to design and evaluate a blockchain-based equities trading platform for transaction security and traceability. Provable Atomic Consensus for Trading (PACT), a blockchain-based architecture for regulated financial institutions’ trading environments, combines hybrid consensus with a privacy-preserving cryptographic approach. A hybridized consensus process for efficient transaction finality, zero-knowledge proof enabled atomic settlements for instant delivery vs. payment while protecting commercial secrecy, and regulator-accessible smart contracts for real-time compliance checks are used in the PACT algorithm PACT found a 20% reduction in consensus finality time, 53% reduction in proof verification time, 56% improvement in smart contract vulnerability, and 42% improvement in auditability index on a permissioned blockchain with hardware-accelerated smart contracts. The study indicated 35.6% lower throughput and 41.7% lower Tx volume over 10 validators. Latency over 10 validators is 24% lower and Tx volume is 23.2% lower than existing research models. Blockchain improves securities infrastructure speed, reliability, and transparency without affecting compliance, according to studies.

sec.title: Blockchain fundamentals for security trading
sec.p: Brand equity, perceived usability, and perceived technical utility all play a role in investors’ acceptance and trust in online securities trading platforms1. These behavioural elements bolster advances centred on the infrastructure and show how crucial the user experience is to the achievement of transparent, secure trading systems.Despite technological advancements enhancing trading efficiency, concerns about financial market volatility impact the securities trading process through price fluctuations, settlement delays, and opaque record keeping2. The research challenges underscore the need for robust solutions to improve market stability, reduce trade risks, and enhance participants’ trust3. Advanced cryptographic algorithms like Zero Knowledge Proofs provide an innovative balance between transaction transparency and ensure sensitive trading information remains secure4. Hence, the research applies Blockchain technology to explore the potential of decentralized, immutable, and cryptographically secure architecture, which can transform the transparency and security of securities market infrastructure5. Blockchain ensures secure, tamper-proof transactions through decentralized control, while its shared ledger enhances transparency, trust in trading, and compliance enforcement6.

Integrating blockchain enhances security through real-time anomaly identification, safeguarding securities trading7. The potential of revolutionizing the stock market by improving transparency, tracking trade securities, automating financial margins, and operational efficiency of investments in stocks has been achieved by blockchain8. Analyzing the influencing factors of stock trading, monitoring market risk, and mitigating risks underscoring the impact on regulatory and privacy concerns9. Blockchain-based tokenization enhances transparency and accessibility by enabling lower entry barriers, reduced costs, and decentralized, 24/7 global trading10. Handling complex transaction behavior in decentralized finance (DeFi) based transactions in trading demonstrates the task and achieves lower transaction cost and secured tracing of trades in financial institutions11.

The potential of blockchain role is highlighted in improving transparency, security, and reliability in financial systems, aiming to reduce fraud and automate compliance12. Blockchain technology improves transparency and trading efficiency and provides financial development and transaction participants13. The key analysis impacts of securities trading are transparency, adoption, infrastructure, and financial stability, which are explored by blockchain technology14. The decentralized technology validates data transparency while sharing trades and monitoring the access control, local offloading, and mitigating resource failure risk15. Inefficient centralized middlemen and obsolete infrastructure threaten settlement efficiency, audit transparency, and securities trading fraud prevention. These inefficiencies lead to declining settlements, confusing record-keeping, and greater systemic risk, requiring modern, decentralized solutions16.Applying blockchain significantly reduces settlement cycles, enabling near-instantaneous transactions compared to existing trading process security analysis. The research insights analyze user (Buyer and Seller) trust, stock value exchange, verification, and transparency in secure trade transactions with the use of blockchain17.

sec.title: Research problem identification & motivation
sec.p: The traditional securities trading system faces challenges related to transparent, opaque trading practices, delayed settlements, and fraud vulnerabilities, which impact the security trading market efficiency and investor trust. These limitations of the existing securities trading model motivate the provision of improved security and traceability in securities trading transactions based on the blockchain using the PACT framework. The research aims to design and evaluate a blockchain-based securities trading model that enhances transaction security, settlement efficiency, improved regulatory compliance, trade traceability, and privacy preservation in securities trade transactions.

PACT adds a time-bounded commit strategy and validator-aware DAG reference for regulated securities settings, unlike FLUID. The hybrid consensus technique uses Byzantine Fault Tolerance (BFT) and Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) concepts. PACT optimizes for deterministic finality under compliance constraints using regulatory audit hooks, structured trade validation windows, and atomic delivery-versus-payment conditions, unlike FLUID. This design provides efficient consensus and simple integration with privacy-based zk-SNARK and smart contract compliance layers, surpassing current hybrid approaches. This permits auditable, high-frequency securities trading that meets regulatory and latency-sensitive criteria.
The key innovations of the research contribution with its novelty are listed below:

list-item.p: To develop a PACT framework that evaluates a blockchain-based securities trading model that enhances security and transparency among trade traces, transaction securities, and regulatory compliance.
To design a hybrid consensus model that integrates BFT and DAG for achieving trade finality.
To create a zero-knowledge proof, atomic settlements offer instant delivery-versus-payment without revealing asset balances.
To implement a smart contract-based compliance framework that validates real-time anomaly detection and maintains security and user (buyer/seller) privacy.

sec.p: The research work is structured as a literature review and benchmarking in Sect. 2, and the proposed PACK framework explanation with corresponding input data source is given in Sect. 3. Result analysis and performance benchmarking in Sect. 4 with various security and transparency-related evaluation metrics. Section 5 contains the research conclusion, potential limitations, and future research scope.

sec.title: Literature review & benchmarking
sec.p: Prabanand & Thanabal18 presented a model for smart contracts based on deep learning to ensure the safety of financial transactions. The model employs Dynamic Deep Temporal Context Networks (DyDTCN) based BlockChain (BC) with an improved Dynamic Butterfly-Billiards Optimization Algorithm (DB2OA) in a private Ethereum consortium database (PEC). When tested on encrypted consumer financial data, the model achieved throughput improvements of 41% and accuracy improvements of up to 6.7% compared to conventional approaches. Nevertheless, the study’s generalizability is limited due to the absence of thorough validation across multiple financial settings and real-world dataset disclosure.

Wang et al.19 analyzed blockchain’s impact on securities trading through creative models, risk assessment, and real-world case studies, including Shenzhen and Shanghai Stock Exchanges, Nasdaq Linq. While illustrating the usefulness of smart contracts and decentralized custody systems, the research lacks explicit algorithmic models, dataset transparency, and quantitative performance measures. A significant drawback of wider scalability and regulatory harmonization is the lack of consistent assessment across worldwide use cases.

Vijay Anand et al.20 introduced a blockchain architecture for secure, privacy-preserving fraud detection in decentralized transactions utilizing Federated Learning (FL) and convolutional neural networks (CNNs). Despite the lack of transparency regarding datasets and benchmarking information, key technologies such as smart contract-driven model management, homomorphic encryption, and differential privacy are included. A noteworthy shortcoming is the lack of scalability testing under high-frequency transaction loads and real-world deployment validation.

Alotaibi et al.21 Improving openness in federal procurement in the United States is the goal of the GovBlockchain architecture, which uses Hyperledger Fabric as a research approach in the design science of price trade-offs and enhances security transparency. The conceptual model mimics procurement records without using a real-world dataset to provide better accountability and traceability. However, future research should expand its reach and incorporate more sophisticated technologies. The study has drawbacks, such as an overemphasis on procurement and an absence of integration with advanced analytics or real-world implementation.

For safe Internet of Things (IoT) data exchange, Li et al.22 suggested a Trust (T)-based crowdsourced data trading system that makes use of deep reinforcement learning (DRL) and a blockchain-enabled smart contract (BSC). The method was tested on Ethereum with 1000 devices using the Remix smart contract platform. It incorporates DRL, which stands for actor-critic-based selection, abbreviated as traceable trust correction. Data quality improved by 17.3% and trading security by up to 63.9%. However, issues with scalability and real-world deployment in high-volume IoT contexts are still unresolved.

Abdennadher et al.23 employed a simulation method to assess how blockchain technology (BCT) influences stock trading procedures’ trading, clearing, and settlement phases. Using a dataset containing process metrics, transaction kinds, and volumes. The findings reveal markedly better process efficiency and shorter transaction times, particularly for larger quantities. The results cannot be applied to other nations or assets because of the qualitative methodology and the lack of research comparing blockchain adoption rates.

An evaluation of security and privacy-preserving technologies such as Zero Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) and multiparty computations in blockchain finance is carried out in this research conducted by Joseph24 using statistical studies (Chi-Square, regression) and empirical testing on the Ethereum testnet. It exposes algorithmic bias, MPC scalability difficulties, and efficiency-privacy trade-offs, including computational burden (+ 60%) and increasing gas expenses (0.02→0.05 ETH). Additional research on hybrid PET models and quantum-resistant approaches is necessary due to the absence of data from real-world deployments, which is a significant restriction.

Chen et al.25 differentiate between blockchain-backed and non-blockchain-backed asset-backed securities (ABS) issuances in China using a comparative analysis algorithm applied to a small-sample dataset. The results show that blockchain technology can cut yield spreads by 31.4 basis points, or 13%, and minimize the need for credit upgrades. However, the study does not evaluate long-term success or wider market adoption, and its scope is limited to China and a small sample.

sec.p: Shafin et al.26 propose a hybrid blockchain architecture with permissioned and permissionless layers for safe, scalable, and instantaneous elastic electric car charging micropayments. Smart contracts for billing automation, privacy-preserving identity authentication, and consensus optimization meet vehicle mobility needs. This paper shows hybrid blockchain technologies can be used in high-throughput, high-integrity domains. Mission-critical applications are increasingly using hybrid consensus approaches, and this framework’s approach to balancing trust, scalability, and latency is conceptually connected to its financial aims.

Shafin et al.27 proposed architecture makes use of cutting-edge cryptographic techniques including elliptic curve encryption, zk-SNARKs, and Schnorr-based verifiable random functions to address issues like incentive alignment, anomaly detection, and stake distribution. Testing with 25 benchmarked systems confirmed that the system’s decentralization, usual blockchain attack vector defenses, and ability to process over 1700 transactions per second were all achieved by its holistic architecture. Surprisingly, the consensus works admirably on low-end hardware, using an average of barely 16.1% of the CPU power of each validator. To provide safe and scalable securities trading without compromising auditability or compliance with regulations, the PACT framework relies on these findings to optimize consensus and design systems.

As discussed in Table 1, a comparative analysis of existing research related to blockchain in securities trading systems highlights the need for applied algorithms, results achieved, and unresolved research challenges. There is a lack of real-world deployment and validation18,20,21, computational overhead from privacy-preserving technologies like ZKPs22 and multiparty communication24, and regulatory-compliant auditing mechanisms23,24. Several context-specific25 or restricted research fail to combine key trading security operations like execution, settlement, and regulatory compliance into a uniform framework. The comprehensive and modular PACT framework addresses the issues mentioned above. It uses hybrid consensus for scalability and durability, zk-SNARK-based atomic settlement for private but DvP verifiable, and regulator-accessible smart contracts for auditable regulatory compliance without compromising confidentiality. As Joseph noted, PACT’s AI-driven detection of the bias layer reduces transaction processing structural disparities24. PACT bridges the gap between theoretical potential and real-world applicability by integrating hybrid PET models for enhanced compliance and privacy, laying the groundwork for reliable and effective blockchain-based securities trading.

sec.title: A blockchain-based provable atomic consensus for trading
Data collection
sec.p: The Binance dataset provides trade data from a decentralized exchange built on blockchain infrastructure, as observed in28. It offers insights into order cancellations, execution delays, and trading behavior in centralized and regulated environments. Using klines indicates raw trade provides buyer and seller flags and quote quantities. Including diverse asset types mentioned in Table 2 and market modalities further enhances the generalizability and robustness of the proposed PACT model, especially in scenarios involving compliance enforcement, fraud detection in high and low trade cases, and delivery-versus-payment atomic settlements.

Binance’s freely available dataset was used to test the blockchain-based PACT framework, which allows securities trading, in a simulated regulated market. Binance is most known for its cryptocurrency trading data, but its comprehensive, timestamped transaction records give it a great foundation for modelling financial exchanges. The raw data could not be used directly because cryptocurrency exchanges are open 24/7, including weekends and holidays, and have substantial regulatory and structural differences from traditional stocks. Asset IDs were redesigned to match equity instruments’ price behaviour, lot size, and settlement procedures. Instead, the dataset was updated to meet traditional stock market trading times.
The collection includes time-series recordings for:

list-item.p: USD-M and COIN-M Spot and Futures Trading.

sec.p: Raw data comprises tradeId, price, quantity, timestamp, buyerMaker, and bestMatch, all timestamped at millisecond or microsecond precision.

Trading outside of New York Stock Exchange or London Stock Exchange hours was eliminated during preprocessing, which translated continuous trading activity into scheduled sessions. We also created synthetic regulatory criteria including know-your-customer verification status, institutional or retail trader tags, and compliance norms to make securities markets seem regulated. Smart contract compliance measures can be assessed using this way. These measures include anomaly detection, transaction volume restrictions, and participant eligibility validation. To test how well the proposed approach could detect anomalous patterns like spoofing and wash trading, we simulated these patterns using statistical deviations in transaction volume and price behavior. This tested how effectively the framework could detect patterns.

To guarantee that the new dataset was adequate for stress testing in real-world scenarios, additional validation was performed. The blockchain model showed that it can handle high-frequency trading with minimum delay by comparing deal throughput, latency, and finality measures to traditional exchange patterns. The validated data allowed evaluation of consensus performance, proof verification time, and regulatory audit queries under different market loads. Because of this, the tailored dataset was used to evaluate the PACT design’s openness, velocity, and safety in a regulatory and operational framework that reflects modern securities markets.

sec.p: The collection is in CSV format, compressed inside ZIP packages, and includes comprehensive time-series data for all major cryptocurrencies, including BTC, ETH, and BNB, represented by ticker symbols. Each file is daily or monthly, with millisecond timestamps (before 2025) or microseconds (after 2025). This enables precise reconstruction of real-time trading scenarios needed to validate latency, throughput, and atomicity under realistic blockchain transaction volumes. Using data USD-M & COIN-M provides detailed insights into margin-based trading activities, supporting the simulation of atomic settlements under trade conditions. Each category includes fields critical to modeling consensus timing, proof verification efficiency, and smart contract responsiveness under varying transaction volumes and validator conditions.

The PACT framework, the central invention of this research, improves transparency and security based on blockchain to enhance security in securities trading. Figure 1 shows the overall architectural design of the PACT framework with three main components to create an efficient, secure, and compliant trading system. The hybrid consensus mechanism follows an input trade proposal representation. A directed acyclic graph (DAG) structure ties each transaction to numerous preceding transactions to ensure trade asset traces. Transaction validation uses a Byzantine Fault Tolerant (BFT) consensus algorithm for quick, secure agreement among validator nodes. This approach gives real-time delivery-versus-payment settlement with millisecond trade confirmation. Then, it introduces a zero-knowledge proof-based atomic settlement where Participants can demonstrate their asset sufficiency without providing sensitive balance information using this layer. The settlement method executes asset transfers atomically using cryptographic commitments and ZKP verification, eliminating buyer and seller settlement risk. Finally, the smart contract-based compliance layer enforces participant identity verification, transaction volume restrictions, and real-time anomaly detection. It also allows regulatory bodies to audit and query transactional data securely and privately. This architectural overview shows how the PACT framework meets modern securities trading’s most significant challenges— trust, throughput, latency, and privacy, through a blockchain-based solution.

sec.title: Zero-knowledge proof atomic settlements
sec.p: The objective of zero-knowledge proof atomic settlements (ZK-AS) ensures atomic Delivery-versus-Payment (DvP) using these zk-SNARKs while preserving privacy.

sec.p: Upon verification of the zk-SNARK proof, the trade is atomically settled by updating the asset balances of both the Buyer and the Seller. This ensures the trade coincides, eliminating the risk of one party defaulting after the trade has been agreed upon. The atomic nature of the settlement guarantees the DvP principle, and both assets change hands simultaneously, ensuring fairness and security.

Regulators can utilize the PACT architecture to meet the data transparency and auditability standards imposed by the financial sector. It employs a permissioned blockchain design with zero-knowledge proofs and smart contracts. Trade activities, compliance validations, and settlement outcomes are permanently recorded using structured metadata. This enables secure, real-time audit trails that do not reveal sensitive financial information. Incorporating zk-SNARKs ensures verifiable compliance with regulatory norms, such as balance adequacy and KYC status, while also guaranteeing the preservation of participant anonymity. Financial rules, such as MiFID II and SEC audit mandates, assess the system’s integrity on an ongoing basis. The auditability index provides a quantitative assessment of the framework’s transparency, helping to meet these requirements.

sec.title: Result analysis and insights
sec.p: The existing research framework, such as Dynamic Deep Temporal Context Networks based on Blockchain (DyDTCN-BC)18, Federated Learning (FL) and convolutional neural networks (CNNs)20, and asset-backed securities (ABS)25, is benchmarked for comparative analysis. The performance underscores metrics related to security (consensus finality time, smart contract vulnerability rate, proof verification time, transparency (auditability index), throughput, and latency measures across the benchmark and the proposed PACT framework.

The simulation experiment for evaluating the PACT framework in a blockchain-based securities trading system is designed to assess various performance aspects such as transaction finality, proof verification, smart contract compliance, anomaly detection, and auditability. The experiment uses data from Binance, which has been adjusted to simulate traditional stock market behaviors, including attributes like trade ID, price, quantity, timestamp, and OHLC data, with timestamps at millisecond and microsecond precision. The blockchain setup consists of 21 validator nodes in a permissioned network, with at least 14 nodes required for consensus. A hybrid consensus mechanism combining BFT and DAG is employed for efficient and fault-tolerant transaction validations. At the same time, zk-SNARKs are used for privacy-preserving atomic settlements to ensure secure transactions.

The simulation is conducted within traditional stock market hours, excluding weekends and holidays, and includes both high-frequency and low-volume trades to test the system under different conditions. To evaluate its robustness, the system also tests for anomalous behaviors such as spoofing and trading by introducing statistical deviations in trade volume and price. Key performance metrics such as consensus finality time, proof verification time, auditability, throughput, and latency are measured under different loads. In particular, the system is tested with varying validator node counts (5, 10, and 20) and transaction volumes (500 to 5000 transactions), simulating high-stress conditions.

Additionally, compliance checks are enforced through smart contracts, ensuring all transactions adhere to KYC and AML regulations. The system also ensures that users do not exceed daily or monthly trade volume limits to prevent market manipulation. This comprehensive testing ensures that the PACT framework can efficiently handle high-frequency trades, maintain security, and comply with regulatory requirements in a blockchain-based securities trading environment.

sec.title: Consensus finality time
Proof verification time
sec.p: Optimizing ZK-SNARK generation and verification, as depicted in Fig. 6, PACT reduces the time required to verify proofs. This scheme ensures that proofs can be verified in less time compared to models like DyDTCN-BC, FL + CNN, and ABS. The analysis is significant in blockchain-based systems where the ZK-proof plays a central role in ensuring privacy while verifying the transaction’s correctness.

According to benchmark comparisons, DyDTCN-BC and FL + CNN had average transaction verification times of 212–287 milliseconds, affected by cryptographic overhead and trade volume. However, the PACT framework lowered verification latency to 99 ms and 82 ms in high-throughput circumstances. These investigations reduce average proof verification time by 53.3% for high-frequency trading situations that require real-time transaction validation. Certain performance features are needed for compliant, low-latency, and privacy-protecting institutional securities trading systems.

sec.p: Permissioned blockchain settings can validate functional performance and regulatory compliance with 118 TPS, whereas high-frequency trading (HFT) systems in centralized architectures can deal with millions of messages per second. In decentralized systems, auditability, throughput scalability, and cryptographic assurances trade off. Alternative trading systems (ATS) and post-trade settlement layers need a higher throughput than front-office execution engines. Latency-sensitive HFT contexts require zk-proof parallelization, consensus pipelining, and lightweight post-quantum primitives. We must acknowledge this restriction to position the PACT architecture for use cases in regulated financial infrastructure that value transparency, compliance, and security over ultra-high execution speed.

sec.p: The Binance dataset is well-suited for analyzing consensus latency, atomic settlement, and compliance enforcement; however, it doesn’t cover all aspects of operational and regulatory requirements for institutional securities trading. To tackle this, in future assessments, we intend to include simulations using conventional market datasets, such as NASDAQ TotalView-ITCH or NYSE TAQ. Using these statistics, we can simulate market regulation constraints (such as Reg NMS and MiFID II) on order book depth, institutional order flow, and latency patterns. The goal is to mimic the integration and interoperability of legacy systems with regulatory interfaces, such as compliance APIs and KYC/AML systems, through regulated small-scale deployments in permissioned environments.

Real-world blockchain-based securities trading systems must be interoperable with financial infrastructure. The PACT framework can expose ISO 20,022 and FIX protocol-compliant API interfaces and message translation layers, enabling integration with SWIFT, DTCC, and CSDs. PACT smart contracts can initiate or confirm transactions through off-chain gateways linked to legacy platforms as programmable compliance and settlement agents. Settlement instructions validated by zk-SNARKs on-chain can trigger real-time communications to DTCC’s ITP systems, facilitating asset transfer via traditional custodians.

PACT also interacts with SWIFT gpi (Global Payments Innovation) via secure oracles and permissioned data feeds to coordinate fiat currency payment flows with off-chain DvP protocols. Digital credential schemas or tokenized attestations can map KYC/AML registry identity and compliance data onto the blockchain layer for trust and regulatory monitoring. PACT can layer blockchain features on top of financial rails using interoperability middleware and regulatory APIs, allowing institutions to incrementally adopt blockchain technology without redoing their fundamental infrastructure. This hybrid technique enhances practicality while maintaining PACT’s architectural security, auditability, and privacy.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Despite its significant contributions, the PACT framework has several limitations, including scalability constraints. The current implementation, with 21 validator nodes, may face challenges in extremely high-volume markets. Additionally, the consensus mechanism requires optimization for global-scale adoption. The generation and verification of zk-SNARKs involve significant computational resources during peak trading periods. Future research will extend the PACT framework to support cross-chain settlements, enabling the use of complex financial instruments and inter-exchange trading. By implementing recursive zero-knowledge proofs, it is possible to reduce the computational overhead and improve scalability for high-frequency trading applications. Integrating advanced deep learning algorithms helps enhance anomaly detection and privacy, thereby improving long-term viability.
